solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int_{-1}^{1} \frac{1}{x^{2}} d x \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{x^{2}} d x \quad(\because \quad f(-x)=f(x)) \\
& =2 \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}} \int_{t}^{1} \frac{d x}{x^{2}} \\
& =2 \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\frac{-1}{x}\right)_{t}^{1} \\
& =-2 \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(1-\frac{1}{t}\right) \\
& =2 \lim _{t \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\frac{1}{t}-1\right) \\
& =2 \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(\frac{1}{0+h}-1\right)\\
& =2(\infty-1) \\
& =\infty \;\;\; (Divergent)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 2 A hanger is made of two bars of different sizes. Each bar has a square cross-section. The hanger is loaded by three-point loads in the mid vertical plane as shown in the figure. Ignore the self-weight of the hanger. What is the maximum tensile stress in [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex] anywhere in the hanger without considering stress concentration effects?
Question 3 Creep of concrete under compression is defined as the
solution: Under sustained compressive loading, deformation in concrete increases with time even through the applied stress level is not changed. The time dependent component of strain is called creep. Hence, correct answer is (A).

options.A:
increase in the magnitude of strain under
constant stress
options.B:
increase in the magnitude of stress under
constant strain
options.C:
decrease in the magnitude of strain under
constant stress
options.D:
decrease in the magnitude of stress under
constant strain

question: Question 4 A singly reinforced concrete beam of balanced section is made of M20 grade concrete and [latex]\mathrm{Fe} 415[/latex] grade steel bars. The magnitudes of the maximum compressive strain in concrete and the tensile strain in the bars at ultimate state under flexure, as per IS 456: 2000 are _______ respectively. (round off to four decimal places)
Question 5 In cement concrete mix design, with the increase in water-cement ratio, which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: As the water-cement ratio increases, the porosity in the hardened concrete increases and hence the strength decreases. Also, as water-cement ratio increases, ducts higher water availability, the workability increases. Hence, correct answer is (A).

options.A:
Compressive strength decreases but workability
increase
options.B:
Compressive strength increases but workability
decreases
options.C:
Both compressive strength and workability
decrease
options.D:
Both compressive strength and workability
increase

question: Question 6 The specific gravity of a soil is 2.60 . The soil is at [latex]50 \%[/latex] degree of saturation with a water content of [latex]15 \%[/latex]. The void ratio of the soil is
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{s}} & =2.60 \\
\mathrm{~S} & =50 \% \\
\mathrm{w} & =15 \%
\end{aligned}
[/latex] We know, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{e}_{\mathrm{s}} & =\omega \mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{s}} \\
\mathrm{e} \times 0.5 & =0.15 \times 2.60 \\
\mathrm{e} & =\frac{0.15 \times 2.60}{0.5} \\
\mathrm{e} & =0.78
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 7 A group of 9 friction piles are arranged in a square grid maintaining equal spacing in all directions. Each pile is of diameter [latex]300 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] and length [latex]7 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]. Assume that the soil is cohesionless with effective friction angle [latex]\phi^{\prime}=32^{\circ}[/latex]. What is the center-to-center spacing of the piles (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) for the pile group efficiency of [latex]60 \%[/latex] ?
solution:
[latex]
\mathrm{n}=9
[/latex] Dia. of pile [latex]=300 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] Length of pile [latex](\mathrm{L})=7 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] Using the Converse Labarre formula. [latex]m=3, \quad n=3[/latex] [latex]
n_{g}=1-\frac{\theta}{90} \frac{[m(n-1)+n(m-1)]}{m n}
[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
0.6 & =1-\frac{\theta}{90} \times \frac{3 \times 2+3 \times 2}{3 \times 3} \\
\frac{\theta}{90} \times \frac{12}{9} & =0.4 \\
\theta & =\frac{0.9 \times 9 \times 90}{12} \\
\tan \theta & =\tan \left(\frac{0.4 \times 9 \times 90}{12}\right) \\
\frac{d}{s} & =\tan \theta \\
\frac{0.3 \mathrm{~m}}{\mathrm{~s}} & =0.5095 \Rightarrow \mathrm{S}=0.588 \mathrm{~m}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Alternatively, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Group efficiency }=\frac{\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{ug}}}{\mathrm{n} \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{us}}} \\
& \Rightarrow 0.6=\frac{\frac{1}{2}(\gamma \mathrm{l}) \tan \delta(2 \mathrm{~S}+\mathrm{d}) \times 1 \times 4}{9 \times \frac{1}{2}(\gamma \mathrm{l}) \tan \delta(\mathrm{pdl})} \\
& \Rightarrow 0.6 \frac{(2 \mathrm{~S}+\mathrm{d}) \times 4}{9 \times \pi \mathrm{d}} \\
& \Rightarrow \mathrm{~S}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{0.6 \times 9 \times \pi \times 0.3}{4}-0.3\right]=0.486
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Note:
As the exact answer of spacing is not matching with the given options by E Converse-Labarre formula, therefore we will use alternative method to find spacing.

solution: When super critical stream enters a mild (m) channel section, the type of flow. Pofile would be [latex]M_{3}[/latex] or [latex]S_{1}[/latex].

question: Question 10 Which one of the following statements is TRUE for Greenhouse Gas (CHG) in the atmosphere?
solution: Green House Gas allow short wave radiation to pass through to the earth surface and absorbs the long wavelength radiation coming from the earth surface.

solar radiation to the earth surface, and allows
the long wavelength radiation coming from the
earth surface to pass through.

GHG allows the incoming long wavelength solar
radiation to pass through to the earth surface,
and absorbs the short wavelength radiation coming from the earth surface.

radiation to pass through to the earth surface,
and allows the short wavelength of radiation
coming from the earh surface to pass through
options.D:
GHG allows the incoming short wavelength
solar radiation to pass through to the earth
surface, and absorbs the long wavelength
radiation coming from the earth.

question: Question 11 [latex]G_{1}[/latex] and [latex]G_{2}[/latex] are the slopes of the approach and departure grades of a vertical curve, respectively. Given [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \lt \left|G_{2}\right|[/latex] and [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \neq\left|G_{2}\right| \neq 0[/latex] Statement 1: [latex]+G_{1}[/latex] followed by [latex]+G_{2}[/latex] results in a sag vertical curve. Statement 2: [latex]-G_{1}[/latex] followed by [latex]-G_{2}[/latex] results in a sag vertical curve. Statement 3: [latex]+G_{1}[/latex] followed by [latex]-G_{2}[/latex] results in a crest vertical curve. Which option amongst the following is true?
solution: Given, [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \lt \left|G_{2}\right|[/latex] and [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \neq\left|G_{2}\right| \neq 0[/latex] Statement 1: [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \lt \left|G_{2}\right|[/latex] This results in a vertical sag curve. Statement 2: [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \lt \left|G_{2}\right|[/latex] This results in a vertical crest curve. Statement 3: [latex]\left|G_{1}\right| \lt \left|G_{2}\right|[/latex] This results in a vertical crest curve.

options.A:
Statement 1 and Statement 3 are correct;
Statement 2 is wrong
options.B:
Statement 1 and Statement 2 are correct;
Statement 3 is wrong
options.C:
Statement 1 is correct; Statement 2 and
Statement 3 are wrong
options.D:
Statement 2 is correct; Statement 1 and
Statement 3 are wrong

question: Question 12 The direct and reversed zenith angles observed by a theodolite are [latex]56^{\circ} 00^{\prime} 00^{\prime \prime}[/latex] and [latex]303^{\circ} 00^{\prime} 00^{\prime \prime}[/latex], respectively. What is the vertical collimation correction?
solution: In above example of both direct zenith angle and reversed zerwith angle are smaller than true value. The error [latex](\varepsilon)=\left[\frac{\left(\phi_{1}+\phi_{2}\right)-360}{2}\right][/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] here, error [latex]=\frac{\left(56^{\circ}+303^{\circ}\right)-360^{\circ}}{2}=-30^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad[/latex] Correction [latex]=+30^{\prime}[/latex]

question: Question 13 A student is scanning his 10 inch [latex]\times [/latex] 10 inch certificate at 600 dots per inch (dpi) to convert it to raster. What is the percentage reduction in number of pixels if the same certificate is scanned at 300 dpi?
solution: DPI = Dots Per Inch, it should be noted that DPI is not dots per square inch. [latex]\%[/latex] reduction in number of pixels [latex]=\frac{10 \times 600 \times 10 \times 600-100 \times 300 \times 10 \times 300}{10 \times 600 \times 10 \times 600} \times 100[/latex] [latex]=\frac{600^{2}-300^{2}}{600^{2}} \times 100[/latex] [latex]=75 \%[/latex]

question: Question 14 If [latex]M[/latex] is an arbitrary real [latex]n \times n[/latex] matrix, then which of the following matrices will have non-negative eigenvalues?
solution:
[latex]
M X=\lambda X
[/latex] [latex][\lambda[/latex] is eigen value of [latex](M)][/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
M M X & =\lambda M X \\
M^{2} X & =\lambda(\lambda X) \\
M^{2} X & =\lambda^{2} X
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[\lambda^{2}\right.[/latex] (non negative) is eigen value of [latex]\left.\mathrm{M}^{2}\right][/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
M X & =\lambda X \\
M^{\top} X & =\lambda X
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[M, M^{\top}\right.[/latex] have same eigen values] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& M M^{\top} X=\lambda M X \\
& M M^{\top} X=\lambda(\lambda X) \\
& M M^{\top} X=\lambda^{2} X
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[\lambda^{2}\right.[/latex] (none negative) is eigen value of [latex]\left.M M^{\top}\right][/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
M X & =\lambda X \\
M^{\top} X & =\lambda X \\
M^{\top} M X & =\lambda M X \\
M^{\top} M X & =\lambda(\lambda X) \\
M^{\top} M X & =\lambda^{2} X
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[\lambda^{2}\right.[/latex] (non negative) is eigen value of [latex]\left.M^{\top} M\right][/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
M X & =\lambda X \\
M M X & =\lambda M X \\
M^{2} X & =\lambda(\lambda X)
(M^T)^2 X&= \lambda ^2 X 
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]\left[\because M, M^{\top}\right.[/latex] have same eigen value] [latex]
\left(M^{\top}\right)^{2} X=\lambda^{2} X
[/latex] [ [latex]\lambda^{2}[/latex] is eigen value of [latex]\left(M^{\top}\right)^{2}[/latex] which non negative] Hence, option A, B, C, D are correct.

question: Question 16 Consider the following three structures: Structure I: Beam with hinge support at A, roller at [latex]C[/latex], guided roller at [latex]E[/latex], and internal hinges at [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]D[/latex]. Structure II: Pin-jointed truss, with hinge support at [latex]A[/latex], and rollers at [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]D[/latex]. Structure III: Pin-jointed truss, with hinge support at [latex]A[/latex] and roller at [latex]C[/latex]. Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution:
Unstability in beam can be checked (i) If support reactions are not enough. (ii) If reactions are concurrent. (iii) If reactions are parallel. (iv) If there is mechanism. where as for truss also along with the above given
points the triangular panels are generally stable. But, a virtual inspection must be conducted to
understand the stability (I) It is unstable as it shows mechanisms. Also to understand if we apply a vertical force at
slider side, the deflected shape will be as follows. (II) The frame is internally stable but all the
reactions are concurrent and meeting at hinge A,
and the frame can rotate about A. Hence, it is unstable. (III) The frame is unstable because it cannot resist
shear in DE and AB since DE and AB are slender
members.

question:
Question 17 Identify the waterborne diseases caused by viral
pathogens:
solution:
Water Borne Disease caused by (i) Bacterial -- (a) Typhoid
(b) Cholera (ii) Virus -- (a) Jaundice (Hapatitis virus)
(b) Poliomyetitis (iii) Protozoa -- (a) Amoebic dysentry

question:
Question 18 Which of the following statements is/are TRUE for
the Refuse-Derived Fuel (RDF) in the context of
Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) management?
solution: (A) is false. The Higher Heating Value (HHV) of Refuse-Derived Fuel (RDF) processed from Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) is typically higher than the HHV of unprocessed MSW. This is because RDF processing removes non-combustible materials from MSW and concentrates the combustible fraction. (B) is true. RDF can be produced in various forms including pellets, fluff, and powdered form. The form of RDF depends on the specific process and intended end use. (C) is partially true. RDF processing typically removes a significant portion of the inorganic fraction of MSW, but not all of it. The remaining inorganic fraction is typically mixed with the RDF product. (D) is false. RDF can be used as a fuel in a variety of combustion systems, including those that burn oil. In fact, RDF is often used as a supplemental fuel in cement kilns and other industrial processes that also use oil as a fuel.

options.A:
Higher Heating Value (HHV) of the unprocessed
MSW is higher than the HHV of RDF processed
from the same MSW.
options.B: RDF can be made in the powdered form
options.C:
Inorganic fraction of MSW is mostly converted
to RDF.
options.D: RDF cannot be used in conjunction with oil.

question: Question 19 The probabilities of occurrences of two independent events [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] are [latex]0.5[/latex] and [latex]0.8[/latex], respectively. What is the probability of occurrence of at least [latex]A[/latex] or [latex]B[/latex] (rounded off to one decimal place)?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
& P(A)=0.5 \\
& P(B)=0.8
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Probability of occurence of atleast [latex]A[/latex] or [latex]B=[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{P}(\mathrm{A} \cap \mathrm{B})[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
P(A \cap B) & =P(A)+P(B)-P(A \cap B) \\
& =0.5+0.8-P(A) \times P(B) \\
& =0.5+0.8-0.5 \times 0.8 \\
& =1.3-0.4 \\
& =0.9
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 20 In the differential equation [latex]\frac{d y}{d x}+a x y=0[/latex], [latex]a[/latex] is positive constant. If [latex]y=1.0[/latex] at [latex]x=0.0[/latex], and [latex]y=0.8[/latex] at [latex]x=1.0[/latex], the value of [latex]a[/latex] is ___ (rounded off to three decimal places).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d y}{d x}+\alpha x y & =0 \\
\frac{d y}{d x} & =-\alpha x y \\
\frac{d y}{y} & =-\alpha x d x \\
\frac{d y}{y} & =-\alpha \int x d x+C \\
\text { In } y & =-\frac{\alpha x^{2}}{2}+C \\
\text { Put } y&=1 \text { at }  =0 \\
\ln 1 & =0+C \\
C & =0 \\
\ln y & =-\frac{\alpha x^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
[/latex] Put [latex]y=0.8[/latex] at [latex]x=1[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\ln (0.8) & =-\frac{\alpha}{2} \\
\alpha & =-2 \ln (0.8) \\
\alpha & =0.4462
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 27 Consider a doubly reinforced RCC beam with the option of using either Fe250 plain bars or Fe500 deformed bars in the compression zone. The modulus of elasticity of steel is [latex]2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]. As per IS456-2000, in which type(s) of the bars, the stress in the compression steel [latex]\left(f_{s c}\right)[/latex] can reach the design strength [latex]\left(0.87 f_{y}\right)[/latex] at the limit state of collapse?
solution:
In a doubly reinforced beam, at the limit state of collapse. The strain in the extreme corression fibre will be [latex]0.0035[/latex]. As the compression reinforcement will be below this, the strain in if will be always less than [latex]0.0035[/latex]. For Fe250, the yield strain [latex]=\frac{0.87 \times 250}{2 \times 10^{5}}=0.0010875
[/latex] For Fe500, the yield strain [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =0.002+\frac{0.87 \mathrm{f}_{y}}{E_{s}} \\
& =0.002+\frac{0.87 \times 500}{2 \times 10^{5}} \\
& =0.004175>0.0035
\end{aligned}
[/latex] So, it is possible that [latex]\mathrm{Fe} 250[/latex] can reach upto its yield strain and hence can reach the design strength [latex]0.87 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{y}}[/latex].

options.C:
Both Fe250 plain bars and Fe500 deformed
bars
options.D:
Neither Fe250 plain bars nor Fe500 deformed
bars

question:
Question 31 Consider that a force [latex]P[/latex] is acting on the surface of a half-space (Boussingesq's problem). The expression for the vertical stress [latex]\left(\sigma_{z}\right)[/latex] at any point [latex](r, z)[/latex] with the half-space is given as, [latex]\sigma_{z}=\frac{3 P}{2 \pi} \frac{z^{3}}{\left(r^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{5 / 2}}
[/latex] where, [latex]r[/latex] is the radial distance, and [latex]z[/latex] is the depth with downward direction taken as positive. At any given [latex]r[/latex], there is a variation of [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] along [latex]z[/latex], and at a specific [latex]z[/latex], the value of [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] will be maximum. What is the locus of the maximum [latex]\sigma_{z}[/latex] ?

Question 32 A square footing of size [latex]2.5 \mathrm{~m} \times 2.5 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] is placed [latex]1.0 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] below the ground surface on a cohesionless homogeneous soil stratum. Considering that the groundwater table is located at the base of the footing, the unit weights of soil above and below the groundwater table are [latex]18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] and [latex]20 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], respectively, and the bearing capacity factor [latex]N_{q}[/latex] is 58 , the net ultimate baring capacity of the soil is estimated as [latex]1706 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] (unit weight of water [latex]10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] ). Earlier, a plate load test was carried out with a circular place of [latex]30 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] diameter in the same foundation pit during a dry season, when the water table was located beyond the plate influence zone. Using Terzaghi's bearing capacity formulation, what is the ultimate bearing capacity (in [latex]\mathrm{kPa}_{-}[/latex]of the plate ?

Question 33 A very wide rectangular channel carries a discharge (Q) of [latex]70 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] per meter width. Its bed slope changes from [latex]0.0001[/latex] to [latex]0.0009[/latex] at a point [latex]P[/latex], as shown in the figure (not to scale). The Manning's roughness coefficient of the channel is [latex]0.01[/latex]. What water surface profile(s) exist(s) near the point [latex]P[/latex] ?

Question 34 A jet of water having a velocity of [latex]20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] strikes a series of plats fixed radially on a wheel revolving in the same direction a the jet at [latex]15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. What is the percentage efficiency of the plates ? (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Given water jet velocity [latex]\left(V_{1}\right)=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Wheel velocity [latex](u)=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] [latex]F_{x}=\rho A V_{1}\left(V_{1}-u\right)[/latex] [latex]\%[/latex] efficiency of the plates [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{F_{x} u \times 100}{\frac{1}{2} \rho Q V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{P \times Q\left(V_{1}-u\right) u \times 100}{\frac{1}{2} \rho Q V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2\left(V_{1}-u\right) u \times 100}{V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2(20-15) \times 15}{20^{2}} \times 100 \\
& =37.5 \%
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question:

Question 36 A plot of speed-density relationship (linear) of two roads (Road [latex]A[/latex] and Road [latex]B[/latex] ) is shown in the figure. If the capacity of Road [latex]A[/latex] is [latex]C_{A}[/latex] and the capacity of Road [latex]B[/latex] is [latex]C_{B}[/latex], what is [latex]\frac{C_{A}}{C_{B}}[/latex] ?

Question 37 For the matrix [latex]
[A]=\left[\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 2 & 3 \\
3 & 2 & 1 \\
3 & 1 & 2
\end{array}\right]
[/latex] Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: [latex]A x=\lambda x \ldots[/latex] (i) [latex]A^{T} x=\lambda x \ldots[/latex] (ii) [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]A^T[/latex] both have same eigen values and eigen vectors. [latex]A x=\lambda x \ldots(i)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad A^{-1} A x=A^{-1}(\lambda x)=\lambda A^{-1} x[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad x=\lambda A^{-1} x[/latex] [latex]A^{-1} x=\frac{1}{\lambda} x[/latex] So, eigen value and eigen vector of [latex]A^{-1}[/latex] is [latex]\frac{1}{\lambda} x[/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{x}[/latex].

options.A:
The eigenvalues of [latex][A]^T[/latex]
 are same as the
eigenvalues of [latex][A][/latex]
options.B:
The eigenvalues of [latex][A]^{-1}[/latex]are the reciprocals of
the eigenvalues of [latex][A][/latex]
options.C:
The eigenvectors of [latex][A]^T[/latex]
 are same as the
eigenvectors of [latex][A][/latex]
options.D:
The eigenvectors of [latex][A]^{-1}[/latex] are same as the
eigenvectors of [latex][A][/latex]

question: Question 38 For the function [latex]f(x)=e^{x}|\sin x| ; x \in \mathbb{R}[/latex], which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: [latex]f(x)=e^{x}|\sin x|[/latex] From above graph its clear that for every [latex]x \in \mathbb{R}[/latex] [latex]lim _{h+0} f(x-h)=\lim _{h+0} f(x+h)=f(x)[/latex] So, function is always continuous but in the graph there are corner points so function is not differentiable.

options.A: The function is continuous at all x
options.B: The function is differentiable at all x

question: Question 39 Consider the beam shown in the figure (not to scale), on a hinge support at end [latex]A[/latex] and a roller support at end [latex]B[/latex]. The beam has a constant flexural rigidity, and is subjected to the external moments of magnitude [latex]M[/latex] at one-third spans, as shown in the figure. Which of the following statements is/ are TRUE?
solution: Using equilibrium equations [latex]\left.\sum \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{A}}\right)=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad-\mathrm{M}+\mathrm{M}-\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}} \times(3 \mathrm{~L})=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}}=0[/latex] [latex]\sum F_{V}=0 \Rightarrow R_{A}+R_{B}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{A}}=0[/latex] SFD [latex]\Rightarrow \quad[/latex] No shear force throughout the span. BMD As there is [latex]B M[/latex] in span [latex]C D[/latex], which leads to curvature in CD. i.e. deflection is not zero everywhere.

question: Question 40 Which of the following statements is/are TRUE in relation to the maximum mixing depth (or Height) ' [latex]D_{\max }[/latex] ' in the atmosphere?
solution: The depth of mixing layer in which vertical movement of pollutants are possible is called maximum mixing depth (MMD). An air parcel at temperature rises and cools. The level where its temperature becomes equal to surrounding air gives the maximum mixing depth value. Also, ventilation coefficient = MMD [latex]\times[/latex] Average wind speed High value of ventilation coefficient leads to low air pollution potential.

options.A:
[latex]D_{max}[/latex] is always equal to the height of the layer
of unstable air
options.C:
A smaller [latex]D_{max}[/latex] will have a smaller air pollution
potential if other meteorological conditions
remain same
options.D:
Vertical dispersion of pollutants occurs up to
[latex]D_{max}[/latex]

question:
Question 41 Which of the following options match the test reporting conventions with the given material tests in the table? [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\text{Test reporting convention} & \text{Material test} \\
\hline
\text{(P) Reported as ratio} & \text{(I) Solubility of bitumen} \\
\hline
\text{(Q) Reported as percentage} & \text{(II) Softening point of bitumen }\\
\hline
\text{(R) Reported in temperature} & \text{(III) Los Angeles abrasion test} \\
\hline
\text{(S) Reported in length} & \text{(IV) Flash point of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(V) Ductility of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(VI) Specific gravity of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(VII) Thin film oven test} \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
(I) Solubility of bitumen: It is defined as weight of bitumen soluble in [latex]100 \mathrm{ml}[/latex] of carbon disulphide. (II) Softening point of bitumen: It is the temperature at which bitumen attains a particular degree of softneess. (III) Los angles abrasion test: It is reported as
percentage of material finer than [latex]1.7 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] with respect to total weight. (IV) Flash point of bitumen: It is the lowest temperature at which bitumen catch five momentarily. (V) Ductility of bitumen: Ductility is measured by stretching a standard briquette of bitumen. The distance in [latex]\mathrm{cm}[/latex] that the briquette can be stretched before breaking is the ductility. (VI) Specific gravity of bitumen: It is the ratio of unit weight of bitumen to unit weight of water. (VII) Thin film oven test: It measure mass charge a sample as a percent of initial mass.

question:
Question 42 The differential equation, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{du}}{\mathrm{dt}}+2 \mathrm{tu}^{2}=1
[/latex] is solved by employing a backward differnce scheme within the finite difference framework. The value of [latex]u[/latex] at the [latex](n-1)^{\text {th }}[/latex] time-step, for some [latex]n[/latex], is 1.75. The corresponding time [latex](\mathrm{t})[/latex] is [latex]3.14 \mathrm{~s}[/latex]. Each time step is [latex]0.01 \mathrm{~s}[/latex] long. Then, the value of [latex](u_{n}-u_{n-1})[/latex] is ____ (round off to three decimal places).

Question 43 The infinitesimal element shown in the figure (not to scale) represents the state of stress at a point in a body. What is the magnitude of the maximum principal stress (in [latex]\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex], in integer) at the point?
Question 44 An idealised bridge truss is shown in the figure. The force in Member [latex]U_{2} L_{3}[/latex] is _____  kN (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\sum F_{y}=0, \quad 50-20-20-F_{U_{2} L_{3}} \sin 45^{\circ}=0[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad F_{U_{2} L_{3}}=\frac{10}{\sin 45^{\circ}}=14.14 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Rounding off to one decimal.

question: Question 45 The cross-section of a girder is shown in the figure (not to scale). The section is symmetric about a vertical axis [latex](Y-Y)[/latex]. The moment of inertia of the section about the horizontal axis [latex](X-X)[/latex] passing through the centroid is _____ [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{4}[/latex] (round off to nearest integer).

Question 46 A soil having the average properties, bulk unit weight [latex]=19 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex]; angle of internal friction [latex]=25^{\circ}[/latex] and cohesion [latex]=15 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex], is being formed on a rock slope existing at an inclination of [latex]35^{\circ}[/latex] with the horizontal. The critical height (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) of the soil formation up to which it would be stable without any failure is _____ (round off to one decimal place).

Question 47 A smooth vertical retaining wall supporting layered soils is shown in figure. According to Rankine's earth pressure theory, the lateral active earth pressure acting at the base of the wall is ____ [latex]\mathrm{kPa}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place)

Question 48 A vertical trench is excavated in a clayey soil deposit having a surcharge load of [latex]30 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex]. A fluid of unit weight [latex]12 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] is poured in the trench to prevent collapse as the excavation proceeds. Assume that the fluid is not seeping through the soil deposit. If the undrained cohesion of the clay deposit is [latex]20 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] and saturated unit weight is [latex]18 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], what is the maximum depth of unsupported excavation (in [latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) ? ____

Question 49 A 12-hour storm occurs over a catchment and results in a direct runoff depth of [latex]100 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex]. The time-distribution of the rainfall intensity is shown in the figure (not to scale). The [latex]\phi[/latex]-index of the storm is (in [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places)_____

Question 50 A hydraulic jump occurs in a [latex]1.0 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] wide horizontal, frictionless, rectangular channel, with a pre-jump depth of [latex]0.2 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] and a post-jump depth of [latex]1.0 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]. The value of [latex]g[/latex] may be taken as [latex]10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex]. The values of the specific force at the pre-jump and post-jump sections are same and are equal to (in [latex]\mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places) ____

Question 51 In Horton's equation fitted to the infiltration data for a soil, the initial infiltration capacity is [latex]10 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{h}[/latex]; final infiltration capacity is [latex]5 \mathrm{~mm} / \mathrm{h}[/latex]; and the exponential decay constant is [latex]0.5 \mathrm{~h}[/latex]. Assuming that the infiltration takes place at capacity rates, the total infiltration depth (in [latex]\mathrm{mm}[/latex] ) from a uniform storm of duration [latex]12 \mathrm{~h}[/latex] is ____. (round off to one decimal place)

Question 52 The composition and energy content of a representative solid waste sample are given in the table. If the moisture content of the waste is [latex]26 \%[/latex], the energy content of the solid waste on dry-weight basis is _____ [latex]\mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] (round off to one decimal place). [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|}
\hline
Component & \text{Percent} & \text{Energy} \\ & \text{by mass}  & \text{content} \\ & & \text{as-discarded} \\ & &\text{basis} \\& &   (\mathbf{M J} / \mathbf{k g}) \\
\hline
Food \; waste & 20 & 4.5 \\
\hline
Paper & 45 & 16.0 \\
\hline
Cardboard & 5 & 14.0 \\
\hline
Plastics & 10 & 32.0 \\
\hline
Others & 20 & 8.0 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
Assuming [latex]1 \mathrm{Kg}[/latex] of solid waste [latex]
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text {Component} & \text {Percent}& \text {Mas (Kg)} & \text { Energy} & \text { Energy}\\ & \text{by mass}& & \text{content} & \text{of waste (MJ)}\\

\hline
Food \; waste & 20 & 0.2 & 4.5 & 0.2 \times 4.5=0.9 \\
\hline
Paper & 45 & 0.45 & 16.0 & 0.45 \times 16=7.2 \\
\hline
Carboard & 5 & 0.05 & 14.0 & 0.05 \times 14=0.7\\
\hline
Plastics & 10 & 0.10 & 32.0 & 0.1 \times 32=32 \\
\hline
Others & 20 & 0.20 & 80 & 0.2 \times 8=1.6 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex] Energy produce from [latex]1 \mathrm{Kg}[/latex] work [latex]=13.6 \mathrm{~mJ}[/latex] Moisture content [latex]=26 \%[/latex] Solid content [latex]=100-26=74 \%[/latex] Therefore [latex]1 \mathrm{Kg}[/latex] of waste consist of [latex]=0.74 \mathrm{Kg}[/latex] dry mass [latex]\therefore \quad[/latex] Energy content based on dry weight [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{13.6}{0.74}=18.378 \mathrm{~mJ} / \mathrm{Kg} \\
& \simeq 18.40 \mathrm{MJ} / \mathrm{Kg}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A flocculator tank has a volume of [latex]2800 \mathrm{~m}^{3}[/latex]. The temperature of water in the tank is [latex]15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex], and the average velocity gradient maintained in the tank is [latex]100 / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The temperature of water is reduced to [latex]5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex], but all other operating conditions including the power input are maintained as the same. The decrease in the average velocity gradient (in %) due to the reduction in water temperature is ____ (round off to nearest integer). [Consider dynamic viscosity of water at [latex]15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] and [latex]5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] as [latex]1.139 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] and [latex]1.518 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex], respectively]

Question 54 The wastewater inflow to an activated sludge plant is [latex]0.5 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex], and the plant is to be operated with a food to microorganism ratio of [latex]0.2 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mg}-\mathrm{d}[/latex]. The concentration of influent biodegradable organic matter of the wastewater to the plant (after primary settling) is [latex]150 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex], and the mixed liquor volatile suspended solids concentration to be maintained in the plant is [latex]2000 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}[/latex]. Assuming that complete removal of biodegradable organic matter in the
tank, the volume of aeration tank (in [latex]\mathrm{~m}^{3}[/latex]
, in integer)
required for the plant is _____.
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} 
Q_1&=6.5 m^3/s \\
&=0.5 \times 24 \times 60 \times 60 \\
&=43200 m^3/d\\
\frac{F}{M} & =0.2 (mg/mg-d)\\
\mathrm{S}_0 & =150 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \\ \mathrm{X} & =2000 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{l} \\ \because \quad \frac{F}{M} & =\frac{\mathrm{Q}_0 \mathrm{~S}_0}{\mathrm{VX}} \\ 0.2 & =\frac{43200 \times 150}{\mathrm{~V} \times 2000} \\ V & =16200 \mathrm{~m}^3\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 Trigonometric levelling was carried out from two stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] to find the reduced level (R.L.) of the top of hillock, as shown in the table. The distance between stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] is [latex] 55 \mathrm{~m}[/latex]. Assume stations [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex], and the hillock are in the same vertical plane. The R. L. of the top of the hillock  (in[latex]\mathrm{m}[/latex] ) is _____ (round off to three decimal places) [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline Station &\begin{array}{c}\text{Vertical} \\ \text{angle of} \\
\text {the top of} \\ \text{hillock }\end{array} &\begin{array}{c}\text {Staff} \\ \text{reading} \\
\text {on} \\ \text{benchmark}\end{array} &\begin{array}{c}\text {R.L. of} \\
\text {benchmark}\end{array} \\
\hline P &18^{\circ} 45^{\prime} &2.340 \mathrm{~m} &100.000 \mathrm{~m} \\
\hline Q &12^{\circ} 45^{\prime} &1.660 \mathrm{~m}& \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
While taking reading from [latex]P[/latex], RL of hillock [latex]=H I_P+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]=100+2.34+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] While taking reading from [latex]Q[/latex]. [latex]\mathrm{RL}[/latex] of hillock [latex]=\mathrm{HI}_Q+(\mathrm{x}+55) \tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]=100+1.66+(x +55)\tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] Equating both, [latex]100+2.34+x \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}=100+1.66+(x +55)\tan 12^{\circ} 45^{\prime}[/latex] [latex]2.34+0.339 x=1.66+12.445+0.226 x[/latex] [latex]\therefore x=104.115[/latex] [latex]\quad \therefore \quad[/latex] RL of hillock [latex]
=100+2.34+104.115 \tan 18^{\circ} 45^{\prime}
[/latex] [latex]
=137.682
[/latex]

Question 61 Based only on the truth of the statement 'Some
humans are intelligent', which one of the following
options can be logically inferred with certainty?
solution:
1. "Some humans are intelligent" can be
represented by Venn diagram. 2. "Same human's are intelligent" can be also
represented by Venn-Diagram Being are human is correct so some intelligent
beings are human is also correct. Hence, option (d) can be logically correct. Option
(c) same non humans are intelligent is a possibility
only which true in (1) diagram but false in (2).

question:
Question 62 Which one of the options can be inferred about
the mean, median, and mode for the given
probability distribution (i.e. probability mass
function), P(x), of a variable x?
solution: Median = (-1+1)/2=0 Mode = -13,13 (Date with high probability) Its Bi-Modal data : So, Median [latex]\neq[/latex] Mode

question:
Question 63 The James Webb telescope, recently launched in
space, is given humankind unprecedented access
to the depths of time by imaging very old stars
formed almost 13 billion years ago. Astrophysicists
and cosmologists believe that this odyssey in space
may even shed light on the existence of dark
matter. Dark matter is supposed to interact only
via the gravitational interaction and not through
the electromagnetic-, the weak - or the stronginteraction. This may justify the epithet "dark" in
dark matter. Based on the above paragraph, which one of the
following statements is FALSE?

options.A:
No other telescope has captured images of
starts older than those captured by the James
Webb telescope.
options.B:
People other than astrophysicists and
cosmologists may also believe in the
existence of dark matter.
options.C:
The James Webb telescope could be of use
in the research on dark matter.
options.D:
If dark matter was known to interact via the
strong-interaction, then the epithet "dark"
would be justified.

question: Question 64 Let [latex]a=30 !, b=50[/latex] !, and [latex]c=100 ;[/latex]. Consider the following numbers: [latex]\log _{a} c, \log _{c} a, \log _{b} a, \log _{a} b[/latex] Which one of the following inequalities is CORRECT?

Question 65 A square of side length [latex]4 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] is given. The boundary of the shaded region is defined by one semi-circle on the top and two circular arcs at the bottom, each of radius [latex]2 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex], as shown. The area of the shaded region is [latex]\mathrm{cm}^{2}[/latex].
solution: Top shaded area [latex]=4 \times 2-\frac{\pi 2^{2}}{2}=8-2 \pi[/latex] Bottom shaded area [latex]=\frac{\pi \times 2^{2}}{4} \times 2=2 \pi[/latex] Total shaded area [latex]=8-2 \pi+2 \pi=8[/latex]
